Thought Journal How\'d I get Here? Pros and Cons Bad Behaviors Identify Barriers ABC\'s
Pros and cons icon How\'d I get here icon Bad behaviors icon ABC\'s icon Thought journal icon Identify barriers icon
Thought journals can help you recognize and change unhelpful thought patterns. The purpose of this exercise is to get you into the habit of paying attention to your thoughts. The ABC\'s stand for Activating events, Beliefs, and Consequences. The purpose of this activity to recognize the link between the things that happen to us, unhelpful beliefs/thoughts, and the consequences of these thoughts and events. Already identified the unhelpful behavior you\'d like to change? In this activity we will problem solve… and try to prevent the behavior next time an urge pops up! This activity can help you analyze the chain of events and reactions that contributed to a behavior step by step. So we can prevent it next time. What about good/effective behaviors? When there was a helpful behavior or action that we planned to do but didn\'t, this activity can helps identify what stopped us from doing it. This activity can help you look at things objectively by weighing the pros and cons of continuing or stopping engagement in a specific thought, behavior, or habit. >
Send us a suggestion Have an idea for an activity you think would be helpful?
Begin! Return Next Where did the behavior occur? At what time did it occur? Morning Noonish Afternoon Evening At night Hint: A specific place, i.e home
Situation Details Hint: Re-tell the events that occurred objectively, as if you are watching them in a movie Optional: What happened before you engaged in the behavior? Back Behavior What is the unhelpful behavior or action that you engaged in? Who were you with? If you weren\'t alone, enter who you were with. With others Alone What was going through your mind at the moment? Thoughts Thought Bubble Image Movie Image What is the main emotion you experienced at the time? Review Review Review Your Answers
Submit Edit

What can you do in the moment to distract you from engaging? What can you do that will prevent you from engaging in the future? Insights Gain insights on your unhelpful behaviors, and say goodbye to doing all the detective work yourself! This section connects all the dots for you using your past entries Behavioral Inspection Game Plan Find Thinking Errors Take a look at those thoughts and find out what might have gone wrong. The activity in this section helps you analyze thoughts from previous entries. Some activities had you fill out ways to deal with your unhelpful behaviors. This section puts them all together for you, so you can figure out your next move! Delete item Next icon No data to display! Try filling out more forms for insights. Don\'t Change Cons Don\'t Change Pros Change Cons Change Pros Barriers Back icon Add Entry Select Thought Mental Filter Select A mental filter occurs when you only focus on evidence that supports your unhelpful thought. You may only see one part of the situation and filter the part out Black and White Thinking Black and white thinking occurs when you start thinking in extremes. This error can cause someone to see something as all bad or all good, with no in-between Fallacy of Fairness The fallacy of fairness is rooted in the idea that life is always fair. This thinking error can cause us to focus on how the events occurring or the ways in which we are treated are unfair, which can create resentment or anger Focusing on the Past Focusing on the past can cause us to experience unhelpful thoughts or emotions due to something that happened to us. This can even cause us to feel as if we are in distress or danger Should Statements "Critical words like \"should\" or \"must\" put a lot of pressure and demands on us or the people we are applying to. With this thinking error, once can fail to see that sometimes things get in the way of what we think \"should\" be done" Disqualifying the Positive When we disqualify the positive, we minimize positive things about ourselves, our achievements, the situation, or others. We may say that the good things \"don\'t count\", and make up excuses for them not being significant Generalization When we generalize, we make broad assumptions about something due to some experiences we had. This can take the form of assuming a bad outcome, or seeing patterns which do not exist Personalization When we engage in personalization, we can blame ourselves for things that we are logically not responsible for or are not in out control Thought: Thinking errors: Popup menu button
CogStruct is an app based on clinical Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) created to help anyone target unhelpful behaviors, thoughts, and emotions. CogStruct provides a paperless solution to CBT, by allowing you to do CBT based activities on your phone! \nUsing CogStruct, you can easily fill out worksheets that may help you understand the driving forces behind your unhelpful behaviors, so you can be better equipped to come up with strategies to work on them. In addition, CogStruct allows you to gain valuable insights, by organizing all your worksheet input into helpful graphs and categories. About We take your privacy very seriously, and never share your data with any third party. When you enter information on the app, your data is stored in your account using an instance of Googles own secure database, with enhanced privacy rules to make sure that your data is safe. Privacy Disclaimer Please note that CogStruct is intended to serve as a potential supplement to ones mental health. This app is in no way a replacement for therapy or professional help, and can not serve as a sole resource for ones therapy.\nIn addition, CogStruct is not intended to be used for life threatening issues, if you or someone you know is in a life threatening or harmful situation please do not hesitate to call 911, or the applicable emergency number for your region.
Learn More CBT Cogstruct is based on Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Unlike some other (equally helpful) forms of therapy, CBT focuses on the present. It is designed to examine ones thoughts, behaviors, and emotions in a structured manner. By doing so, one may identify cognitive distortions, understand and regulate their emotional responses, and come up with techniques to change their behaviors. More Activities While the CBT-based worksheets on this app may be a good start or supplement to an existing therapy plan, there are a lot of resources you can utilize if you want to delve deeper. Many mental health professionals are certified in this form of therapy, and would be able to help you explore more. You can also find many more CBT worksheets and exercises for free online, and even more from certified sites for a small subscription fee. Objectivity Some people find it hard to be objective when doing CBT or CBT-based exercises alone. It is always a good idea to have a trained mental health professionals to discuss your responses to the worksheets with. If this is not possible, some people find it helpful to discuss their responses with an understanding friend or family member. Other Therapies If you enjoy the CBT-based exercises on this app, you may want to look into other forms of therapy. Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT) is based on CBT, but focuses on the emotional and social factors. DBT can help people regulate unhelpful emotions, and come up with coping strategies to deal with them and their effects on thoughts and behaviors. DBT can also help people with problems, practice distress tolerance, acceptance, and mindfulness. /nLike CBT, many mental health professionals are trained in this kind of therapy, and free resources exist online if you wish to get a glimpse as to what it entails.
